The potential of AI-powered adaptive learning systems to promote equity and inclusion is a crucial aspect of their implementation. While they can provide personalized support to students who may be struggling, it's essential to address concerns around algorithmic bias to ensure that these systems don't exacerbate existing inequities. This is a critical area of ongoing research and development in EdTech.

It's great to hear that you received positive feedback from educators and policymakers at the conference! Your nuanced approach to exploring the challenges and opportunities of AI-powered adaptive learning systems is likely to resonate with many stakeholders in the EdTech community.

The debate around the role of teachers in AI-powered adaptive learning systems is a common one. Some educators may worry that these systems will replace them, while others see them as a valuable tool to support teaching and learning. By emphasizing the importance of teacher involvement in the development and implementation of these systems, we can ensure that they are designed to augment and support teaching, rather than replace it.

Did you find that there were any other areas of tension or disagreement among stakeholders in your research? For example, were there differing opinions on the role of government or industry in regulating or supporting the development of AI-powered adaptive learning systems?

Also, what's next for your research? Are you planning to continue exploring the implementation and impact of AI-powered adaptive learning systems, or do you have other EdTech-related topics on the horizon?
